def is_divisible(n,x,y):
    return n % x == 0 and n % y == 0

def is_divisible(n, x, y):
    return n % x == n % y == 0

def is_divisible(n, x, y):
    return not n % x and not n % y

""" isdiv works thusly:
Create a function isDivisible(n, x, y)
that checks if a number n is divisible
by two numbers x AND y. All inputs are
positive, non-zero digits.
"""


# isDivisible(3,1,3)--> true because 3 is divisible by 1 and 3
# isDivisible(12,2,6)--> true because 12 is divisible by 2 and 6
# isDivisible(100,5,3)--> false because 100 is not divisible by 3
# isDivisible(12,7,5)--> false because 12 is neither divisible by 7 nor 5

def is_divisible(n,x,y):
    """is divisible checks if a number n is divisible
    by two numbers x AND y. All inputs are
    positive, non-zero digits.

    >>> is_divisible(3,1,3)
    True
    >>> is_divisible(12,2,6)
    True
    >>> is_divisible(100,5,3)
    False
    >>> is_divisible(12,7,5)
    False

    >>> is_divisible(0,1,1)
    Traceback (most recent call last):
     ...
    ValueError: Must be integer greater than 0
    >>> is_divisible(1,0,1)
    Traceback (most recent call last):
     ...
    ValueError: Must be integer greater than 0
    >>> is_divisible(1,1,0)
    Traceback (most recent call last):
     ...
    ValueError: Must be integer greater than 0
    """

    if n < 1 or x < 1 or y < 1:
        raise ValueError('Must be integer greater than 0')

    return n % x == 0 and n % y == 0

def is_divisible(n,x,y):
    return not (n%x or n%y)

def is_divisible(n,x,y):
    return n % x + n % y == 0

def is_divisible(n,x,y):
    return (n % x == 0) & (n % y == 0)
is_divisible = lambda n,x,y: not (n%x or n%y)

def is_divisible(n,x,y):
    return True if n % x == 0 and n % y == 0 else False

def is_divisible(n,x,y):
    return (False, True)[n%x==0 and n%y==0]
is_divisible = lambda n,x,y: not ((n**2)%(x*y))

def is_divisible(n,x,y):
    return n%x==0==n%y

def is_divisible(n,x,y):
    return not (n % x + n % y)
is_divisible=lambda n,x,y: n%x==0 and n%y==0
from math import gcd; is_divisible = lambda n, x, y: not n%(x*y//(gcd(x, y)))

def is_divisible(n,x,y):
    return abs(n) % abs(x) == 0 and abs(n) % abs(y) == 0
is_divisible = lambda n,x,y: (n%x==0)&(n%y==0)
is_divisible = lambda n, x, y: not n % x and not n % y

def is_divisible(n,x,y):
    return True if n%x==n%y==0 else False

"""NOTE: This is NOT an efficient solution, it's just a solution using Python's gcd function"""
"""Imports greatest common divisor (gcd)"""
from fractions import gcd 
"""gcd has been moved to the math module in Python 3.5,
so you should use: from math import gcd"""
def is_divisible(n,x,y):
    """Computes the least common multiple (lcm) -> 
    https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Least_common_multiple#Computing_the_least_common_multiple"""
    lcm = (x*y)/gcd(x,y) 
    """if x divides n, and y divides n, so lcm(x,y) also divides n"""
    return n%lcm == 0

def is_divisible(n,x,y):
    return all([n%m==0 for m in (x, y)])

def is_divisible(n,*args):
    return all(n % i == 0 for i in args)

def is_divisible(n, x, y):
    return all([not n % x, not n % y])

def is_divisible(n,x,y):
    return n % y == 0 if n % x == 0 else False;

def is_divisible(n,x,y):
    return True if (n % x or n % y) == 0 else False

def is_divisible(n,x,y):
    return True if n%x is 0 and n%y is 0 else False

def is_divisible(n,x,y):
    return (n%x is 0 and n%y is 0)

def is_divisible(n,x,y):
    return True if n%x == 0 == n%y else False

def is_divisible(n,x,y):
    return not (n % y) + (n % x)

def is_divisible(n,x,y):
    return not bool(n % y)+(n % x)

def is_divisible(n,x,y):
#    if all(n % x and n % y) == 0:

    return n % x == 0 and n % y == 0

def is_divisible(n,x,y):
    q1, r1 = divmod(n, x)
    q2, r2 = divmod(n, y)
    return True if r1 == 0 and r2 == 0 else False

def is_divisible(n,
                 x,
                 y):

    if (n % x == 0 and
        n % y == 0):

        return True

    return False

def is_divisible(n,x,y):
    return True if ((n % y == 0) & (n % x == 0 )) else False
is_divisible = lambda  n, x, y: (n / x).is_integer() and (n / y).is_integer()

def is_divisible(n,x,y):
    i = n % x
    j = n % y
    return i+j == 0

#Goal: Write a program that determines whether an integer n is divisible by integers x and y and has no remainder.
# The program should return a True or False value.
#General Strategy: Check to see if the remainder value of n / x and n / y is equivalent to zero.
# Use modulus to find the remainders.
# To return a boolean value of both remainders being zero, I can add both remainders together.
# This will work because if both are zero the sum will be zero.
# If not then the sum will be different and the boolean value returned will be false.

def is_divisible(n,x, y):
    # Return a boolean value by checking to see whether the sum of the remainders of n modulus x and n modulus y equals
    # zero.
    return 0 == (n % x) + (n % y)
is_divisible=lambda n,x,y:n/x==n//x and n/y==n//y

def is_divisible(n,x,y):
    return True if (n / x).is_integer() and (n / y).is_integer() > 0 else False

def is_divisible(n,x,y):
    a = n%x
    b = n%y
    return False if bool(a+b) else True

from math import gcd
def is_divisible(n,x,y):
    #your code here
    return True if n//(x*y/gcd(x,y))==n/(x*y/gcd(x,y)) else False
